description: Attested since about 1800. Probably an intensive form of crunch; ultimately derived from the onomatopoeia of a crumpling sound; or perhaps a blend of squeeze +â€Ž crunch.

verbs.description: scrunch (third-person singular simple present scrunches, present participle scrunching, simple past and past participle scrunched)

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To crumple and squeeze to make more compact.

entries.meaning: (with object "one's face") To contract the muscles of one's face so as to draw their facial features together, out of pain, discomfort, uncertainty, etc.
examples: He scrunched his face at his wife's request.
